# Moving Everything One Folder Up in Zsh (Including Hidden Files)

To move all files and directories (including hidden files that start with a dot) from the current directory to its parent directory, you can use one of these commands in zsh:

## Option 1: Using mv with globbing
```zsh
mv *(D) ..
```
The `(D)` glob qualifier makes the pattern match hidden (dot) files as well.

## Option 2: Using a more explicit approach
```zsh
mv ./* ../.  # Move visible files/folders
mv ./.[^.]* ../. 2>/dev/null  # Move hidden files/folders (suppressing errors)
```

## Option 3: Using find
```zsh
find . -maxdepth 1 -not -name "." -exec mv {} .. \;
```

## Important Notes:
- These commands will fail if files with the same names already exist in the parent directory
- If you want to override existing files, add the `-f` flag to the mv command
- Be cautious with these commands, especially when using wildcards
- Consider testing in a safe environment or backing up important data first
